The part about them being alive has been known from almost the beginning.  It's not just some possible theory postulated in a new book for the first time.  I had never heard that there was evidence the pilot flipped switches, attempting to regain control, though.  It's worth pointing out the original test shuttle flights had an ejection system, pressure suits for the flight, and Story Musgrave was instrumental in getting an escape system (though not an ejection one) and pressure suits back onto the shuttles after Challenger.  The Russian shuttle also had ejection seats, and while the US considered them not likely to work well in those circumstances, the fact is there were ejections from SR-71s and it was quite remarkable how well ejection can work, especially when you're protected in a pressure suit. Heck, there was a case where the entire Blackbird disintegrated around the pilot in-flight without even an ejection taking place and he survived due to his pressure suit and automated parachute!

The last week of January is always a somber time for NASA. In the space of six days, the agency recalls three fatal space tragedies: the Apollo 1 fire of Jan. 27, 1967, the Challenger shuttle disaster of Jan. 28, 1986 and the Columbia shuttle accident of Feb. 1, 2003. 
Those dates and the surrounding weeks should be set aside as "no launch" dates in memory of this lost.

"The tank quickly ruptured, igniting the hydrogen fuel and causing a massive, Hindenburg-like explosion. "

There was no "huge explosion".  The vehicle broke up due to aerodynamic and mechanical stresses due to the SRB burn thru that compromised the lower field joint.  There were several events that occured very rapidly after the field joint finally let go that caused vehicular breakup. Big solid rockets should never be used for human space flight.  The Dr. Von Braun German rocket team hated the big solid rockets.  After the German rocket team retired out, Utah had powerful politicians who mandated the big solid rockets for the Space Shuttle Program.  The pressure to use big solid rockets for NASA human space flight is still alive and well today.  Look at the current NASA SLS Program.  The problem with the big solid rockets for human space flight is that you can't turn them off once ignited, posing a safety issue for getting the crew off in the event of a failure.  This has been looked at and studied for years, with no really good solution, but politics still drive their use.  The big solid rockets also make the Air Force Range Safety officers nervous every launch.  What if the Flight Termination System fails?  If so, it is then just a prayer these big solid rockets don't hit a populated area.
